Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master An Shigao of Arsakes during the Later Han Dynasty
The Buddha was at Jetavana AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada-ÄrÄma in ÅšrÄvastÄ«. At that time, the Buddha felt compassion

for all beings in the cycle of birth and death, so he expounded the subtle teachings, distinguishing good and evil, with a total of five paths - people's good and evil deeds have degrees, and their anger has levels of intensity. The heavenly path has no relatives, and always accompanies the good. What are the five paths?
First, the heavenly path; second, the human path; third, the path of hungry ghosts; fourth, the path of animals; fifth, the path of Niraya and Mount Tai hells.
People who do not seek the path to transcend the world have an endless cycle of birth and death, suffering, and come and go in the five paths, unable to be liberated.
The wise and intelligent people are weary of suffering, and when they see a teacher, they serve him. When they do not see him, they think of the teacher's teachings.
The teacher teaches people to avoid evil and do good, and shows people the path to transcend the world.
Parents nurture and raise their children, but only for one lifetime, from old age to sickness and death. The Buddha saves people for ten thousand generations, without end.
The wise and intelligent should contemplate this carefully.
The Buddha said to the disciples:
Listen all!
I will explain to you the misfortune and blessings of good and evil.
The disciples all knelt and said with palms joined:
Yes!
We will accept the teaching.
The Buddha said:
If a person in the world has a compassionate mind and does not kill, they will obtain five blessings from not killing.
What are the five?
First, their lifespan will increase;
Second, their body will be at ease;
Third, they will not be harmed by weapons, tigers, wolves, or poisonous insects;
Fourth, they will be reborn in the heavens, with an infinite lifespan in the heavens;
Fifth, after leaving the heavens and being reborn in the world, they will have a long life.
Those who are now a hundred years old all attained this from not killing in their previous lives.
It is better to be born in suffering than to die in pleasure. Be careful not to commit killing.
The Buddha said:
People in the world do not take others' property, do not pick up lost items on the road, and are not greedy for profit. From this, they obtain five virtues.
What are the five?
First, wealth increases day by day;
second, there is no loss;
third, there is nothing to fear;
fourth, one is reborn in the heavens, with abundant treasures in the heavens;
fifth, coming down from the heavens, one is reborn in the world, and one's wealth is preserved, and officials, thieves, and bandits do not dare to encroach upon or take one's wealth.
Those who now have wealth preserved to old age are all due to not daring to take others' property from past lives.
Loss, whether much or little, causes people to worry and distress.
Loss is not as good as preservation. Be careful not to take others' property!
The Buddha said:
In the world, if one does not violate the wives of others, and does not think of improper things, one obtains five benefits from this.
What are the five?
First, no loss;
Second, no fear of the county government;
Third, no fear of people;
Fourth, to ascend to heaven, and the jade maidens of heaven become one's wives;
Fifth, coming down from the heavens to be born in the world, one has many beautiful wives.
Now, the Venerable One has several beautiful wives, all due to not violating the wives of others in past lives.
What is seen now is clear, so be careful not to violate the wives of others!
The Buddha said:
In the world, if one does not slander others with divisive speech, does not curse others with harsh words, and does not speak falsely or frivolously, one obtains five benefits from this.
What are the five?
First, all words are trusted;
Second, one is loved by others;
Third, one's breath smells fragrant;
Fourth, they attain the heavens and are respected by the gods;
Fifth, coming down from the heavens, they are born in the world as humans with good teeth, and others dare not slander them with evil words.
Those who are seen now, from birth to old age, not being slandered by others, all come from the protection of good speech from the mouth in past lives.
It is so clear, be careful not to falsely slander others!
The Buddha said:
People in the world who do not drink alcohol and become intoxicated, from not being intoxicated, obtain five benefits.
What are the five?
First, when conveying matters to superiors and seeing officials, their words are not mistaken, and they also serve in office as they wish;
Second, household affairs are well managed, and they always have surplus wealth;
Third, borrowing and seeking profit is quickly obtained, and they are also respected by others;
Fourth, they attain the heavens and are also respected by the gods;
Fifth, those who come down from the heavens to be born in the world are pure, joyful, wise, and understand things, all due to not drinking alcohol in their previous lives.
Be careful not to drink alcohol!
The Buddha said:

People in the world who do not hold knives and sticks to threaten others, who do not harm others with their hands and feet, who do not fight and separate others, who do not impose on others what they do not desire, attain five virtues from this.
What are the five?
First, the body is strong and healthy;
Second, sleeping and rising are always peaceful;
Third, they are protected and watched over by the devas, nÄgas, and spirits;
Fourth, they ascend to the heavens, and the bliss in the heavens is boundless;
Fifth, coming down from the heavens to be born in the world, the body is complete and free from illness.
Those who are seen to be free from illness from birth to old age, all attain this due to not harming others in their previous lives.
Be clear about this and never add harm to others!
The Buddha said:
If a person in the world is harmonious in mind and does not give rise to anger, they respect the wise and endure the foolish. From this, they attain five virtues.
What are the five?
First, they are praised by others;
second, people see them and are all delighted;
third, their body is at ease and also well-moisturized;
fourth, they ascend to the heavens, and in the heavens, they are upright and pure;
fifth, from the heavens, they descend and are reborn in the world, and they are kind-natured and upright and beautiful.
Now, those who are seen as excellent, the best among ten thousand people, are all due to their harmonious mind, kind nature, and forbearance from past lives.
Do not give rise to anger, be clear about this, and never give rise to anger towards others!
The Buddha said:

If a person in the world is filial to their parents, respects the elderly, is humble and polite, kneels first and stands up last, speaks last and stops first, and always teaches bad people to do good, they will obtain five blessings from this.
What are the five?
First, they will be respected and loved by others;
second, others will praise their goodness;
third, they will be joyful in their own minds;
fourth, they will ascend to the heavens and be respected and loved by the gods;
fifth, when they come down from the heavens to be reborn in the world, they will be favored by the people.
Those who are now seen to have a good heart, be filial, and be favored by the people, are all due to their filial piety and respect for the elderly in their past lives.
It is clear like this, so one should be filial and respectful to the elderly!
The Buddha said:
If a person in the world uses admonitions and good intentions to respectfully serve the elderly, with complete etiquette, they will obtain five blessings from this.
What are the five?
First, one will obtain a good official position;
Second, one will be quickly promoted in office, and gain profit from buying and selling;
Third, the common people will be delighted to see one;
Fourth, the gods in the heavens will be delighted to see one;

Fifth, coming down from the heavens to be reborn in the world, one will become the child of kings, nobles, and high officials, all due to the blessings created by practicing rituals and accumulating merit in past lives.
It is clear like this, so be careful not to be arrogant towards others!
The Buddha said:

If a person is not stingy or greedy in the world, likes to give generously, and has affection for relatives and poor people in the family, if a beggar child always makes them full of food and drink, and their clothes are also complete and good, they will obtain five benefits from this.
What are the five?
First, wealth and possessions will increase day by day;
Second, they will be praised by the people of the world;
Third, they will be respected by the state, prefecture, and country;
Fourth, one will ascend to the heavens and be attended to by the heavenly beings;
Fifth, one will descend to the human realm from the heavens and be born into a wealthy and happy family, respected by the masses, all due to the practice of generosity and virtue in past lives.
For those who are clear about this, they should also practice virtue and generosity!
The Buddha said:

In the human realm, there are wise ones who are well-versed in the scriptures, such as Å›ramaá¹‡as and practitioners. If one happily goes to them to inquire about the path to transcendence, with a mind free from jealousy, greed, and arrogance, one will attain five virtues from this.
What are the five?
First, one will attain wisdom;
Second, one will have much learning and knowledge, and see much;
Third, one will be respected by many;
Fourth, one will ascend to the heavens and be recognized for one's learning;
Fifth, one will descend to the human realm from the heavens and immediately become well-versed in the scriptures and teachings, respected by the state, and revered by the people.
Now, those who are seen to be well-versed in the scriptures and understand the Way, all of this is due to the virtues and practices of the Way cultivated in past lives.
In this way, it is clear that the Way and virtue can be practiced!
After the Buddha finished speaking the sutra, all the disciples rejoiced and bowed to the Buddha.
The Buddha said:
Listen, I will speak of the evil that comes from doing evil!
All the disciples joined their palms and said:
Yes!
We will receive the Buddha's teachings!
The Buddha said:
People in the world who delight in killing and have no compassionate heart, from this they obtain five evils.
What are the five?
First, a short lifespan;ğŸ”½Second, much fear;
Third, many enemies;

Fourth, after ten thousand years, the soul enters the Taishan Hell. In the Taishan Hell, one undergoes poisonous pain, burning, steaming, roasting, stabbing, butchering, cutting, pressing intestines, and breaking bones. One wants to live but cannot. The crime of killing is great, and one emerges only after a long time.

Fifth, coming out of the hells, one is born as a human, but one's life will always be short. One may die in the womb, die immediately after birth, die within a few tens or hundreds of days, or die within a few tens of years.

Now, those who see people with short lives, disfigured bodies, incomplete limbs, crippled, bald, hunchbacked, blind, deaf, mute, with blocked noses, or without hands and feet, with blocked orifices, are all caused by butchering, hunting, trapping, and fishing in past lives, and killing mosquitoes, flies, turtles, and lice.
It is so clear, do not commit killing!
The Buddha said:

In the world, people steal from others, rob others, forcibly take others' wealth, seek profit unjustly, deceive others to obtain wealth, use light scales, small measures, and short rulers to cheat others, or use heavy scales, large measures, and long rulers to take advantage of others, pick up lost items on the road and take what is not theirs, borrow debts and loans without returning them, and evade people by bumping into them. From this, they obtain five evils.
What are the five?
First, wealth and possessions are gradually depleted;
Second, they are quickly caught by the king's law, and few escape punishment;
Third, their bodies are never at ease, and they always harbor fear, also deceiving themselves;
Fourth, after death, their souls enter the Taishan Hellâ€”in the Taishan Hell, they are examined and punished for millions of offenses, suffering the consequences of their actions;

Fifth, those who come out of the hells repay their debts according to their lightness or heaviness. Some become slaves, some become oxen, horses, mules, donkeys, camels, pigs, sheep, geese, ducks, chickens, and dogs. All the birds, beasts, fish, and turtles are those who owe debts.
The sutra says:
Debts do not rot. This is what it refers to!
Now, those who are seen as lowly animals are all due to their greed for profit and forcefully taking others' wealth in their past lives.
The hardships of animals are like this. Seeing the present is clear. Be careful not to take others' wealth!
The Buddha said:
People in the world who are licentious and violate others' wives obtain five evils from this.
What are the five?
First, the family is not harmonious. Husband and wife often fight and often lose money and wealth;

Second, fearing the county government, always engaging in flogging and punishment, the king's laws are severe, and one will be held accountable for one's own faults, with many deaths and few survivors;
Third, deceiving oneself, always fearing others;

Fourth, entering the Taishan Hellâ€”in the Taishan Hell, an iron pillar is always burning red, and one always embraces it, due to the offense of violating others' wives, one receives this misfortuneâ€”thus for many thousands of years, the body is finally destroyed;
Fifth, coming out of the prison, one is born as a chicken, duck, bird, or goose, the soul and spirit are formless, and what one clings to is called a name.
Now, chickens and ducks are seen to be licentious, not avoiding their mothers and children, and also have no sense of propriety.

There are also those who are faithful like dogs and horses. Even animals have enough faith, but chickens and ducks are licentious and alone have no contentment. They all follow their past lives from the previous world, being licentious and committing adultery with others' wives, and receive this body of chickens and ducks, to be eaten by others.
Such hardships are innumerable.
Be so clear and careful not to commit adultery with others' wives!
The Buddha said:

People in the world enjoy divisive speech and slander others, enjoy harsh words, false speech, and frivolous speech, are self-important, slander the noble path, envy the virtuous and talented, and disparage the highly capable. From this, they obtain five evils.
What are the five?
First, having many enemies and resentments;
Second, deceiving oneself, and from this others all do not believe;
Third, frequently encountering misfortune;

Fourth, entering the Taishan Hell - in the Taishan Hell, ghosts pull out one's tongue from the neck, or cut off one's tongue with a burning iron hook, or pierce one's throat with a burning iron awl. Desiring to die but not able to, desiring to live but not able to, unable to speak - like this for many thousands of years;
Fifth, coming out of the hells, one becomes a human with bad speech, teeth that are either missing or chipped, a lisp, slurred speech, or heavy speech, or mute and unable to speak.
Now seeing those who are like this, they are all from slandering people with double tongues in their previous lives, and from slandering the sages' path in their past lives.
It is like this, clear and distinct, so one should be cautious with bad speech!
The Buddha said:
People who enjoy drinking alcohol and getting drunk in the world have thirty-six losses.
What are the thirty-six losses?

First, when people drink alcohol and become intoxicated, they cause their children to disrespect their parents, and officials to disrespect their rulers, with no distinction between ruler and ruled, father and son;
Second, their speech becomes confused and erroneous;
Third, when intoxicated, they become garrulous and talkative;
Fourth, when intoxicated, they reveal others' hidden secrets;
Fifth, when intoxicated, they urinate in public places without any sense of shame;
Sixth, they fall asleep in the streets and cannot return home, or lose the belongings they are carrying;
Seventh, when intoxicated, they are unable to maintain their composure;ğŸ”½Eighth, when intoxicated, they walk with their heads down, looking up, or stumbling, and may fall into ditches;
Ninth, when intoxicated, they trip and fall, and upon getting up, may injure their face;
Tenth, when intoxicated, they make mistakes in buying and selling and act recklessly;
Eleventh, when intoxicated, they neglect their duties and do not worry about making a living;
Twelfth, their wealth and possessions are depleted;
Thirteenth, when drunk, one does not think of one's wife and children's hunger and cold;
Fourteenth, when drunk, one shouts and curses, not avoiding the king's laws;
Fifteenth, when drunk, one unties one's clothes and takes off one's pants and skirt, running around naked;
Sixteenth, when drunk, one enters other people's houses, pulling at their wives and daughters, speaking nonsense and causing chaos, the faults are boundless;
Seventeenth, when passing by others, one wants to fight with them;
Eighteenth, stomping on the ground and shouting, alarming the four neighbors;
Nineteenth, when drunk, one kills insects and reptiles;
Twentieth, when drunk, one beats and strikes the objects in the house, smashing them;
Twenty-first, when drunk, the family members view one as a drunkard, speaking recklessly;
Twenty-second, associating with evil people;
Twenty-third, distancing oneself from the virtuous and good;
Twenty-fourth, when drunk and lying down, one's body feels as if sick;
Twenty-fifth, when drunk, one vomits like a foul-smelling beast, and one's own appearance is despised by one's wife and children;
Twenty-sixth, when drunk, one's mind desires to go out and run wild, avoiding nothing like an elephant or wolf;
Twenty-seventh, when drunk, one does not respect wise ones who study the scriptures, does not respect Daoist masters, and does not respect Å›ramaá¹‡as;
Twenty-eighth, when drunk, one indulges in sexual desires, fearing and avoiding nothing;
Twenty-ninth, when drunk, one is like a madman, and people run away upon seeing it;
Thirtieth, when drunk, one is like a dead person, no longer recognizing anything;
Thirty-first, when drunk, one may develop a swollen face or a wine disease, becoming withered and yellow;
Thirty-second, devas, nÄgas, and spirits all consider alcohol to be evil;
Thirty-third, one's close friends and acquaintances will distance themselves from one;
Thirty-fourth, when drunk, one may squat and stare at officials, or be beaten and have one's eyes gouged out;

Thirty-fifth, after ten thousand parts, one will enter the Taishan Hell, where molten copper will always enter the mouth, burn the stomach, and pass through, making it difficult to seek life or death for thousands of years;
Thirty-sixth, coming out of hell, one will be born as a human, always foolish and ignorant.
Those who are now seen to be foolish and ignorant are all due to their delight in drinking alcohol in their past lives.
It is clear like this, so one should be cautious about drinking!
Alcohol has thirty-six faults, and those who drink alcohol all commit the thirty-six faults.
The Buddha said:

People who delight in holding sticks to frighten others, using their hands and feet to inflict pain on others, delight in fighting and separating others, and forcefully giving others what they do not like, obtain five evils from this.
What are the five?
First, deceiving oneself, and also being hated by others;
Second, the body becomes fearful;
Third, they will often be sick;
Fourth, they will enter the Taishan Hell and receive punishments according to their actions for a long time, for ten thousand years;
Fifth, after coming out of the hells, they will be born as humans with many illnesses and bodies that are not free from pain.
Those who are seen to have many illnesses now are all caused by enjoying inflicting pain on others in past lives. Being sick is not as good as being strong and healthy.
It is like this, clear and distinct. Be careful not to inflict harm on others!
The Buddha said:

People who always enjoy anger and are not harmonious in the world, who are angry at the wise and also angry at the foolish, who do not distinguish between good and evil but only want to be angry, obtain five evils from this.
What are the five?
First, they burn their own bodies;
Second, they also confuse their own minds;
Third, they are uneasy when lying down or getting up, and may worry, become angry, or kill themselves;
Fourth, entering the Taishan Hell, suffering poisonous pain for many thousands of years;
Fifth, after leaving the Taishan Hell, being born as a human with a constantly ugly face, with a withered and dark yellow complexion.
Now, those who have an ugly complexion, all from their past lives, from delighting in anger, resulting in an ugly face and an unattractive complexion.
Thus it is clear, be careful not to be angry!
The Buddha said:

In the world, those who are not filial to their parents, do not respect the elders, and always become angry towards others who are filial to their parents and serve the elders, not delighting in doing good, obtain five evils from this.
What are the five?
First, always having bad dreams;
Second, being disliked by others;
Third, having a bad reputation;
Fourth, entering the Taishan Hell, being punished for many thousands of years;
Fifth, if one comes out from the hells and is reborn as a human, one will have a bad temper and be disliked by the people.
Those who are now seen to have a bad temper and be disliked by the people all come from their past lives, from not being filial to their parents and not respecting the elders.
It is like this, clear and distinct, be careful not to be arrogant!
You should be filial and respectful to the elders.
The Buddha said:
People in the world who are not filial to their elders, who lack propriety, who are arrogant and self-important, who are self-indulgent and self-assertive, obtain five evils from this.
What are the five?
First, losing one's position;
Second, deceiving oneself;
Third, not being respected by others;
Fourth, entering the Tai Shan hells and being punished for many thousands of years;
Fifth, coming out from the hells and being reborn as a lowly and ugly person, despised by others.
Now, those who are seen as lowly and inferior are all due to their arrogance and disrespect for elders in their past lives.
Be cautious and do not be arrogant!
The Buddha said:

If a person obtains wealth and property in the world, but is stingy and unwilling to give in charity, does not look favorably upon the poor, does not provide for them, does not serve Å›ramaá¹‡as, those who are learned in the scriptures and the Way, does not give to beggars, and if they do not dare to eat and drink to their fill or wear clothes to their satisfaction, they will incur five evils from this.
What are the five?
First, they deceive themselves and are not respected by others;
Second, people all call them slaves to money;
Third, they always bear shame;

Fourth, falling into the realm of hungry ghosts, suffering unbearably, for a thousand or a hundred years unable to obtain water to drink, seeing from afar a river or valley stream, rushing to drink from it, the water then turns into molten copper or pus and blood that cannot be drunk. Such suffering is indescribable.

Fifth, coming out from the realm of hungry ghosts, reborn as a human, one will be poor and starving, begging from others, the vertebrae supporting each other, unable to obtain alms, and people will spit on and scold them.
Now seeing poor and begging people, they all come from the past lives due to stinginess and greed, unwilling to give in charity.
It is so clear, be careful not to be stingy and greedy!
The Buddha said:

People in the world who are wise and virtuous, if they do not enjoy going to ask the path to transcendence, are jealous of those with high talent, and slander the virtuous, they will obtain five evils from this.
What are the five?
First, lack of wisdom;
Second, little knowledge;
Third, not being respected by others;
Fourth, entering the Taishan Hell - entering the Taishan Hell, being punished for many thousands of years;
Fifth, after coming out of the prison, being born as a foolish person with no knowledge, the same as an animal.
Now seeing those who are foolish and cannot distinguish right from wrong, all come from their past lives not liking the Way and virtue, and being jealous of the lofty.
It is like this, clear and distinct, one should be careful to practice the Way!
The Buddha said:
People who seek longevity obtain longevity, those who do not seek longevity do not obtain longevity;
Those who seek illness obtain illness, those who do not seek illness do not obtain illness;
Those who seek good looks and beauty obtain good looks and beauty;
Those who seek ugly looks obtain ugly looks;
Those who seek charm obtain charm, those who do not seek charm do not obtain charm;
Seeking the lowly, one obtains the lowly; seeking wealth, one obtains wealth; seeking poverty, one obtains poverty;
Seeking to be well-versed in the scriptures and understand the Way, one obtains to be well-versed in the scriptures and understand the Way; seeking ignorance, one obtains ignorance.
If a person does good, they obtain good; with various merits, they ascend to the heavens; if they become a human, they obtain nobility and also obtain uprightness.
If a person does evil, they obtain evil; with various offenses, they either enter the mountains and hells, or fall into the hungry ghost realm, or fall into the animal realm;
If they manage to become a human, they will be lowly and poor, ignorant, and also ugly.
It is like a person planting bitterness and obtaining bitter fruits, planting sweetness and obtaining sweet fruits.

The long fruits are like planting the five grains; planting rice obtains rice, planting beans obtains beans. It is like a person doing good and obtaining good, doing evil and obtaining evil!ğŸ”½The precepts of transmitting far and connecting with the great discernment,
The precepts of deeply believing and guarding the one in the obstructed and concealed,
Vigorously and resolutely, one abstains from violence and chaos. Benevolence and gentleness, one abstains from not cutting off.
Broad-minded and magnanimous, one abstains from doubt. Deeply clear and relaxed, one abstains from later times.
Cutting off and overflowing, one abstains from rashness. Many people and long words, one abstains from being unreal.
The wise ones abide in precepts, and practicing them has three kinds of goodness.
Seeing respect and much seeking is foolish, and upon the end of life, one receives a heavenly body.
Abiding in precepts and practices are exhausted, and with wisdom, one controls the mind and practices.
Practice reaches the utmost, and all that should be received is cut off.
From precepts, one can extinguish suffering. Precepts are supreme in the three times.
Controlling and subduing the evil poisonous dragon, one does not violate those who have precepts.
Excellent! Those with precepts are venerable. With faith, one can make companions.
This is the Way, not the words of an ordinary person. Therefore, precepts are called venerable.
Precepts are venerable and good to rely on. The body will never be burned.
Having already slept peacefully at night, one's dreams are also joyful.
Being respected by the assembly, one's power and goodness are for one's own body.
Dharma-seeing is for one's own honor, abandoning the world to become the Heavenly King.
I am the sole honored one in the world, I have already escaped the world's troubles,
All of this is the human and heavenly world, just like me comparing the demon's army.
Only the Buddha has experienced hardships, innumerable even in eons,
Coming and going in the five paths, unable to fully weave the thread,
Secretly arranging one's gains, crying out and seeing the shortness.
Those who pay homage to the Buddha today, with a single mind all join palms,
From paying homage one ascends to the heavens, and attains long life among humans.
The Buddha is the most honored and awakened, having already manifested perfect wisdom,
One should first pay homage to the Dharma assembly, whose kindness and virtue are like a river or sea.
Therefore I expound the sacred scriptures of the Buddha,
From the causes and conditions of the origin, there are good and evil deeds.
Extensively collecting and compiling, following the essential meaning of the sutras,
Gathering and narrating like the Buddha's instructions, the deeds of blessings and misfortune.
The Buddha has already realized the Dharma, Brahma and Indra came down to request,
The Venerable then compiled and expounded the sutra, the essential is difficult to see and hear.
Suffering arises from the causes and conditions of suffering, the end of suffering is the most venerable,
In accordance with the eightfold path, the cessation of suffering is purity.
From action there is the fruit of suffering, expounded by the hero of men,
This origin is from the mind, toilsome action arises from this.
The one who removes and heals all toils, this is the wonderful essence of practice,
Therefore it is explained in sequence, truly like the Great Sage Venerable.
Therefore, attach to the scriptures, allowing the world to observe the Dharma,
In accordance with the correct, without doubt, what the wise should take.
It is also not that the gods transform it, causing misfortune and blessings to be without conditions,
It is also not that it is naturally so by nature, nor can it be transmitted by time.
If it is in heaven, how can there be no conditions? Time and nature are also like this.
The superior and the inferior, in reality, are not without practice.
From delusion comes toil, this toil comes from practice,
Having done, it is again surpassed, listening to this is not of one kind.
Patching together the wonderful meaning of the sutras, and the miscellaneous essentials of the Vinaya,
Sufficient to know the reasons of the world, each section is clearly distinguished.
The divine transformation resolves doubts and knots, using the sutras to appear in the world,
Good conduct has the reward of blessings, one should not be unaware of this.
Having done unrighteous actions, upon death one falls into the evil paths,
Immediately one sees King Yama, the king has pity and then binds them, saying:
Infancy, old age, sickness, and death, admonishing them to be punished,
Knowing there are five executioners, why not cultivate virtue?
The best of bodily, verbal, and mental actions are only precepts and giving.
What is your intention alone, that you cannot do good?
At that time, the criminal heard the king's admonishment with the Dharma,
and, knowing he had no good conduct, he entered fear and replied,
It is only because of associating with bad friends, hearing ordinary and unlawful words,
and sitting in greed and confusion that I am unable to cultivate virtuous goodness.
The king said, People are difficult to obtain, but having obtained them, why not do good?
What is difficult to understand about your nature, that you create the actions of hell out of resentment?
You originally gave rise to this evil, which was not done by your parents,
not by Å›ramaá¹‡as or adepts, not by your lord, not by my teaching.
Out of foolishness and a happy mind, you created this unwholesome karma,
which you yourself have done, and now you will receive its retribution.
The five messengers created, with loyal and upright words of instruction,
Then King Yama silently did not speak with them.
Then he recorded the criminals and placed them in Yama's realm,
Leading them to enter hell, seeing the evil, greatly alarmed and frightened.
First entering the black rope hell, large and small all crying out,
Next entering AvÄ«ci, the raging fire burns their bodies.
Treading on thorns and hot earth, directly crossing boiling ash water,
The iron hells are a total of sixteen, reaching the sword leaf tree.
Because people commit evil, causing there to be this hell,
Therefore listing their original actions, next manifesting what should be received,
Up to thousands of millions of years, being born and immediately killing.
Because of this, many grudges are formed, harming virtuous and heroic people,
Giving rise to false accusations and no faults, separating and ruining people's friends,
